comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: AD-5/A-1E Skyraider Bu No 133927 in Light Gull Gray and Insignia White with last five digits of serial number across center tail. Above this is US Navy aviation tail code 7Y from NAS Detroit Selfridge. a4skyhawk.org/2e/navy-tail-codes.htm Side number 51 on engine cowl. Prior to 1970, certain Navy aircraft belonged to a Naval Air Station or Facility without connection to any squadron. Also before 1970, those aircraft that were part of a Naval Reserve Training Unit belonged to the station they were based at, not a squadron. Naval Air Facility Detroit at Selfridge ANGB, Michigan; en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selfridge_ANGB www.globalsecurity.org/military/facility/selfridge.htm Selfridge Air National Guard Base is on the north side of Detroit, Michigan, along the western shore of Lake St. Clair and is home of many units, including Air Force Reserve, Air National Guard, Army, Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard. The Douglas Skyraider originally served with the US Navy from the 1950s and flew off aircraft carriers both in peace time and combat during the Vietnam War. After retirement from the US Navy many single and dual seat A-1 Skyraiders were acquired by the US Air Force, overhauled, modified and repainted for service mainly in South East Asia. Douglas A-1E Skyraider 133927 was transferred to the USAF as 52-133927. While with the 1st Special Operations Squadron 56th Special Operations Wing based at Nakhon Phanom Royal Thai Air Force Base near the border with Laos, on June 28 1969 this aircraft was shot down by "automatic weapons fire" near Muong Soui, Xiangkhoang Province over the land locked nation of Laos. Both Major Bagwell and Lieutenant Colonel W. D. Neal bailed out manually without use of the 'Yankee' seat escape system and were fortunately rescued. www.flickr.com/photos/my_public_domain_photos/6063044652
